test_cases.issue_description: Customer is unable to change their plan immediately through the online portal and is forced to wait until the next billing cycle
test_cases.test_scenario: Test that a customer can upgrade their plan immediately through the online portal without being restricted by the next billing cycle
preconditions: Customer has an active account
Customer has a plan that can be upgraded
Customer has used most of their data for the current cycle
test_steps: Step 1: Log in to the customer portal
Step 2: Navigate to the plan management section
Step 3: Attempt to upgrade the plan to a higher tier
Step 4: Verify that the option to upgrade immediately is available
Step 5: Select the option to upgrade immediately and verify that the prorated charge is calculated correctly
test_cases.expected_result: The customer is able to upgrade their plan immediately through the online portal without being restricted by the next billing cycle, and the prorated charge is calculated correctly
test_cases.actual_issue: The online portal does not allow customers to upgrade their plan immediately and forces them to wait until the next billing cycle, leading to customer frustration and unnecessary support calls
edge_cases: Test with different data usage scenarios
Test with multiple upgrades in a single billing cycle
test_cases.customer_impact: Customer frustration, unnecessary support calls, and potential loss of business due to inability to meet customer needs in a timely manner

test_cases.issue_description: Port request gets stuck due to missing middle initial in customer's name
test_cases.test_scenario: Test that the web portal's device activation form requires and validates the customer's full name, including middle initial, to match the name on their existing account
preconditions: Customer has an existing account with a carrier, such as Verizon
Customer has a new phone to activate on the Total Wireless web portal
test_steps: Step 1: Create a test account on the web portal with a name that includes a middle initial
Step 2: Attempt to activate a new phone on the test account, entering only the first and last name in the activation form
Step 3: Verify that the form validation checks for a middle initial and prevents submission if it is missing
Step 4: Enter the complete name, including middle initial, and verify that the activation process proceeds without issues
test_cases.expected_result: The web portal's device activation form requires and validates the customer's full name, including middle initial, and the activation process completes successfully
test_cases.actual_issue: The current form design does not account for middle initials, causing port requests to get stuck and resulting in service delays and customer dissatisfaction
edge_cases: Test with different types of names, such as names with suffixes (e.g. Jr., Sr.) or non-English characters
Test with different carrier accounts, such as AT&T or T-Mobile
test_cases.customer_impact: Service delays, customer dissatisfaction, and potential loss of business due to frustrating user experience

test_cases.issue_description: Customer is charged for international roaming without notification when phone connects to a stronger foreign tower near the border
test_cases.test_scenario: Test that the system notifies customers when their phone connects to a foreign tower for roaming, especially in border areas
preconditions: Customer has an active international roaming plan
Customer is near the US-Mexico border
Foreign tower signal is stronger than US tower signal
test_steps: Step 1: Enable international roaming on the customer's account
Step 2: Simulate the customer's phone connecting to a foreign tower near the border
Step 3: Verify that the customer receives a roaming notification or warning
Step 4: Check the customer's usage details to ensure accurate roaming charges are applied
test_cases.expected_result: The customer receives a notification or warning when their phone connects to a foreign tower for roaming, and accurate roaming charges are applied to their account
test_cases.actual_issue: Customers are not receiving notifications when their phone connects to a foreign tower, resulting in unexpected roaming charges
environmental_dependencies: Mobile device with international roaming capabilities
Strong foreign tower signal near the US-Mexico border
edge_cases: Customer is in an area with weak US tower signal
Customer has a phone with automatic network selection enabled
Customer is using a phone with a specific operating system or firmware version
test_cases.customer_impact: Unexpected roaming charges and lack of transparency in billing

test_cases.issue_description: Pricing discrepancy between product page and checkout page for device purchase
test_cases.test_scenario: Verify that pricing information is consistent and clearly indicates any conditions (e.g. new line activation) on the product page and checkout page
preconditions: User is logged in to their account
User has an existing line to upgrade
User selects a device with conditional pricing (e.g. new line activation)
test_steps: Step 1: Navigate to the product page of a device with conditional pricing (e.g. Samsung Galaxy A54)
Step 2: Verify the price displayed on the product page
Step 3: Proceed to checkout with the selected device
Step 4: Verify the price displayed on the checkout page
Step 5: Check for any clear indications of conditional pricing (e.g. 'Price includes new line activation discount')
test_cases.expected_result: The price displayed on the product page and checkout page is consistent, and any conditions (e.g. new line activation) are clearly indicated on the product page
test_cases.actual_issue: Pricing discrepancy between product page and checkout page due to unclear conditional pricing information
edge_cases: Test with different devices and pricing conditions (e.g. new line activation, upgrade, bring-your-own-device)
Test with different user account scenarios (e.g. new customer, existing customer with multiple lines)
test_cases.customer_impact: Customer time wasted, trust, and potential loss of sales due to pricing confusion

test_cases.issue_description: Plan change buttons are non-responsive for customers with multiple add-ons
test_cases.test_scenario: Test plan change functionality for customers with multiple add-ons
preconditions: Customer has an account with multiple add-ons (e.g. international calling and mobile hotspot)
Customer is using a supported browser (e.g. Chrome)
test_steps: Step 1: Log in to the customer portal with a test account that has multiple add-ons
Step 2: Navigate to the plan change page
Step 3: Click on the plan options buttons
Step 4: Verify that the plan change feature responds as expected
test_cases.expected_result: The plan change buttons should respond and allow the customer to change their plan
test_cases.actual_issue: The plan change buttons are non-responsive and do not allow the customer to change their plan
edge_cases: Test with different combinations of add-ons
test_cases.customer_impact: Customers are unable to change their plans online, leading to frustration and potential churn

test_cases.issue_description: Promotional code not valid for existing customers, despite being sent to their email address
test_cases.test_scenario: Test that promotional codes sent to existing customers via email are clearly marked as invalid for their account type
preconditions: Existing customer account with email address
Promotional code sent to existing customer email address
test_steps: Step 1: Log in to the customer portal with an existing customer account
Step 2: Attempt to apply a promotional code sent to the existing customer email address
Step 3: Verify that the system checks the customer's account type before applying the code
Step 4: Verify that the system displays a clear error message if the code is not valid for the customer's account type
Step 5: Verify that the promotional code email sent to the customer clearly indicates any restrictions on its use (e.g. new customers only)
test_cases.expected_result: The system should clearly indicate that the promotional code is not valid for the existing customer's account type, and the email should clearly state any restrictions on its use
test_cases.actual_issue: The system allows existing customers to attempt to apply promotional codes that are only valid for new customers, without clear indication of the restriction
edge_cases: Test with different types of promotional codes (e.g. percentage off, dollar amount off)
Test with different customer account types (e.g. individual, business)
test_cases.customer_impact: Customer frustration and wasted time due to unclear promotional code restrictions

test_cases.issue_description: Mobile app crashes when selecting a new device for upgrade on Android devices with more than 100 apps installed
test_cases.test_scenario: Test device upgrade feature on Android devices with varying number of installed apps
preconditions: Android device with Total Wireless mobile app installed
More than 100 apps installed on the device
Device upgrade option available in the app
test_steps: Step 1: Launch the Total Wireless mobile app on an Android device
Step 2: Navigate to the device upgrade section
Step 3: Select a new device for upgrade
Step 4: Verify if the app crashes or throws an error
Step 5: Repeat steps 2-4 with different numbers of installed apps (e.g., 50, 100, 150) to identify the threshold for the crash
test_cases.expected_result: The mobile app should allow device upgrade selection without crashing, regardless of the number of installed apps
test_cases.actual_issue: The mobile app crashes when selecting a new device for upgrade on Android devices with more than 100 apps installed, due to memory management issues
edge_cases: Test with different types of apps installed (e.g., games, social media, productivity)
test_cases.customer_impact: Core functionality (device upgrade) is unavailable on mobile, forcing customers to use alternative channels, resulting in a poor customer experience

test_cases.issue_description: Customer unable to disable auto-pay in mobile app when enrolled through website
test_cases.test_scenario: Test that a customer can disable auto-pay in the mobile app regardless of where they initially enrolled
preconditions: Customer has auto-pay enabled through the website
Customer has mobile app installed and logged in
test_steps: Step 1: Enable auto-pay for a test account through the website
Step 2: Log in to the mobile app with the test account
Step 3: Navigate to 'Account Settings' then 'Payment Settings'
Step 4: Verify that the option to disable auto-pay is available
Step 5: Disable auto-pay and verify that it is successfully updated
test_cases.expected_result: The customer can disable auto-pay in the mobile app and the change is reflected in their account settings
test_cases.actual_issue: The mobile app lacks the feature to disable auto-pay for customers who enrolled through the website
environmental_dependencies: Mobile device with latest app version
edge_cases: Test with multiple accounts and auto-pay enrollments
test_cases.customer_impact: Customer experience is negatively impacted as they cannot manage their account features through their preferred channel
